channel.title: Anyone have experience with changing ESNs?
channel.description: Just curious here. I was considering buying an old droid or droid 2 global as a test, but I was wondering if anyone here has ever messed around with changing the ESN on android cdma phones. i wonder if itll work on newer phones, or if theyve found ways to block it. Not to do anything illegal, just move my own phones around across cdma networks. Hypothetically speaking of course ;)

item.title: Anyone have experience with changing ESNs?
item.dc:creator: @teh_spede Teh Spede
item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:11, topic:434412”][quote author=Teh Spede link=topic=537133.msg3932074#msg3932074 date=1330768614]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=537133.msg3932053#msg3932053 date=1330762781]

[quote author=Teh Spede link=topic=537133.msg3930257#msg3930257 date=1330617315]

[quote author=Mopman link=topic=537133.msg3930077#msg3930077 date=1330589852]
meant cant* hehe, so i guess the answer is no. weird. must be annoying
[/quote]On the other hand, they do lock sims for phones in europe and ive had problems with sim cards in the past.
[/quote]Thats why you dont fukken buy a phone with a plan.
[/quote]Oh I’ve never bought a phone with a plan.
[/quote]Then there should clearly not be a problem.[/quote]I’ve still had problems with sim cards where I’ve had to order new ones because the old ones start getting bad.

Read full topic

item.source: Anyone have experience with changing ESNs?

item.title: Anyone have experience with changing ESNs?
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

Moparisthebest:

You should be able to just call any provider and have them activate your phone. I don’t know that it is possible to change ESNs at all, is it?

From what I’ve found online researching, with some phones it’s possible. I often see people who have a htc evo that has been flashed to boost, or a samsung epic flashed to virgin. The process, as far as i know, is to take the esn off of a dummy phone and place it onto your phone. The details of how that is done vary from phone to phone. However, the motorola smartphones are notoriously hard… I’ve found one possible way that supposedly works for the droid x, where it is edited in memory at boot. It might work on the droid 1, but I’m not entirely sure.
The reason I ask is because my provider has shit phones unless you buy their top of the line ones, and not very much to offer with a physical keyboard.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have experience with changing ESNs?
